conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the Ampere force on the ν-shaped wire by considering contributions from each segment.
The wire forms two equal-length segments meeting at an angle of 60°; each segment has length l and carries current I.
The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the wire, considered as out of the page.
The force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F = I L × B.
For each segment of length l, the length vector L can be split into components parallel and perpendicular to the magnetic field.
The component of L perpendicular to B is responsible for the force; it's l since the angle is 90°.
The force on one segment is F1 = I * l * B * sin(90°) = I * l * B.
Since there are two identical segments, the total force is F_total = 2 * I * l * B.
The forces on the two segments are in opposite directions along the plane of the paper, canceling each other out.
The net force is zero because the forces cancel each other out.
